body: Is that rebased? I found It's a little confused.

I double-checked: DepthwiseConvolutionOp is called when num_group=num_filter for both mobilenet and resnet. Have you ever measured the speed-ups when running resnet with depth-separable convolutions? I get not speed-up, the performance is even a bit slower when setting num_group=num_filter
fixed in #7609.
thanks

It seems not rebased. The **File Changed** tab should only contain your changes.
Suppose `upstream` is the alias to https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet in your local git. Then type
`git pull --rebase upstream master` to sync with the latest code base and put your commits on top the git history. Type `git log`, you should see your commits for this PR sit on top of the latest upstream commit history.
Is it actually faster? This way slicing happens at runtime

use
```
git fetch upstream
git rebase upstream/master
```
to rebase to master.

It's easier to use the legacy interface for complex operators.

@reminisce Let's update the tutorial later
Yeah, I'm working on the tutorial pr right now. It is also expected to serve as a prerequisite tutorial for contributing sparse operators.
@piiswrong but the operator interface is legacy. Will it be deprecated and removed in near future?

`fcnxs_args = {('arg:%s' % k) : v.as_in_context(ctx) for k, v in fcnxs_args.items()}`
after

then i meet an error
`Traceback(most recent call last):
  File "image_segmentaion.py", line 68, in <module>
    main()
  File "image_segmentaion.py", line 59, in main
    exector = fcnxs.bind(ctx, fcnxs_args ,args_grad=None, grad_req="null", aux_states=fcnxs_args)

    args_handle, args = self._get_ndarray_inputs('args', args, listed_arguments, False)
  File "/mxnet/python/mxnet/symbol.py", line 832, in _get_ndarray_inputs
    raise ValueError('key `%s` is missing in `%s`' % (name, arg_key))
ValueError: key ``conv1_1_weight`` is missing in `args`

`fcnxs_args = {('arg:%s' % k) : v.as_in_context(ctx) for k, v in fcnxs_args.items()}`

You need to add index information to https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/docs/tutorials/index.md just like python.

@nikrao  It is fair to assume that usually precision and recall are used together? Do you think it's better to have one metric that compute both precision and recall as @szha requested?

@eric-haibin-lin @szha I think it's better to have them separate. In many occasions you might use them together, but there are also other examples where you only need one or the other. In the latter case, we will just be spending more time computing (or checking if we should compute) a metric we don't need. You can always create a composite metric by concatenating 2 metrics anyway
Not necessarily. You can compute and bind the update function based on the type of metric in the constructor, since metric is a class.

I ran into the same issue with Macbook Pro late 2015, 10.12.3 Sierra, gcc-7.

I believe that the issue is cause by two versions of OpenCV (2.4.13 and 3.2), because I ran into OpenCV issue several times on my MBP.
So, I tried 2.4.13.2 and 3.20 and HEAD-3649ee3, and only 2.4.13 works, with g++/clang++, not g++-7.
```
mxnet daodao$ g++ --version
Configured with: --prefix=/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/usr --with-gxx-include-dir=/usr/include/c++/4.2.1
Apple LLVM version 8.1.0 (clang-802.0.42)
Target: x86_64-apple-darwin16.4.0
Thread model: posix
InstalledDir: /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Toolchains/XcodeDefault.xctoolchain/usr/bin
```

The most important thing here is to setup OpenCV version explicitly:
```
# setup opencv
ifeq ($(USE_OPENCV), 1)
	CFLAGS  += -DMXNET_USE_OPENCV=1 -I/usr/local/Cellar/opencv/2.4.13.2/include -I/usr/local/include
	LDFLAGS += $(filter-out -lopencv_ts, -L/usr/local/Cellar/opencv/2.4.13.2/lib -lopencv_shape -lopencv_stitching -lopencv_objdetect -lopencv_superres -lopencv_videostab -lopencv_calib3d -lopencv_features2d -lopencv_highgui -lopencv_videoio -lopencv_imgcodecs -lopencv_video -lopencv_photo -lopencv_ml -lopencv_imgproc -lopencv_flann -lopencv_core)
	#CFLAGS += -DMXNET_USE_OPENCV=1 $(shell pkg-config --cflags opencv)
	#LDFLAGS += $(filter-out -lopencv_ts, $(shell pkg-config --libs opencv))
	BIN += bin/im2rec
else
	CFLAGS+= -DMXNET_USE_OPENCV=0
endif
```

Scala build fails
@CodingCat I provided a script `scala-package/dev/change-proj-version.sh` which help to change version easily.

You don't have to since the float32 is the default setup. In most cases, we use float type in training. And the image is normalized into range [0,1]. float32 here means typical single precision float type, while float16 represents half precision float point. It requires less memory on GPU and runs faster for some Nvidia GPUs with half precision units. However, due to the loss of precision, the performance could be worse than single precision one.

Is there any specific reason we can't `library(methods)`?
I've [posted a comment](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/issues/6195#issuecomment-326656584) in #6195 that addresses this issue, maybe it could help you?

In general, it is best not to attach packages when loading another package since it modifies the search path for the existing session and this could cause issues if the user is not aware.  Not the end of the world here, however, since `methods` is now automatically attached when R starts.  I was running into issues trying to isolate everywhere I needed to prefix with `methods::`, so I have reverted to attaching `methods`, with a `packageStartupMessage` alerting the user that it is being attached.
